newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Australian stocks rise on stronger Dow, metals.
newsitem.headline: Australian stocks rise on stronger Dow, metals.

text.p: Australian stocks quickly regained most of Thursday's losses at the opening on Friday after a rebound on Wall Street and with resources well-supported after stronger metal prices and firmer bullion and oil prices.
The All Ordinaries index was 9.4 points up at 2,514.1 at the opening. The index closed 12.9 points down on Thursday. About A$166 million (US$130 million) worth of shares was traded early.
Brokers said the market was likely to trade in a narrow range with few local issues around today and with investors setting their positions ahead of the weekend.
"It is pretty subdued at the moment. I don't think there is anything standing out," said one Melbourne-based broker.
Brokers said chemical group ICI Australia was steady after sliding about nine percent on Thursday after its British parent ICI Plc unveiled plans to sell its stake, worth around A$2 billion.

Market leader BHP topped the turnover charts with over A$100 million worth of trade. The resource giant announced plans after Thursday's market close for a A$636 million share issue based on shareholders buying small parcels of shares.

Traders said oil stocks continued their recent rally buoyed by sharp gains in U.S. cash crude prices. Gold and base metal miners shares were also well-supported after strong gains in metal prices on the LME and higher gold futures in New York.
Banks were broadly firmer, continuing their recent gains ahead of a new round of interim results. National Australia Bank and Westpac both report next week.
